docs.lead_paragraph: The shares of Barclays P.L.C. surged 39 percent in two months after Michael O'Neill, a top executive at Bank of America, was appointed chief executive in February. The market apparently expected Mr. O'Neill, an American who helped oversee the merger of Bank of America and Nationsbank, to shake Barclays, the profitable but troubled British behemoth, from its lethargy.

headline.main: Who'll Take the Driver's Seat?; Barclays at a Crossroads, With Questions on Leadership

docs.abstract: Barclays PLC chairman Sir Peter Middleton denies bank is stalled in either day-to-day operations or strategically as it searches for chief executive to replace Michael O'Neill, who resigned for health reasons after very brief tenure, interview; problems facing new executive discussed; graph of Barclays' stock price; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Trigon Healthcare Inc., the largest health insurer in Virginia, said yesterday that it would stop processing claims for a Medicare program in Virginia and West Virginia and cut 145 jobs, or 3.9 percent of its work force, to focus on its commercial managed health care business. The Richmond-based Trigon, which will stop processing Medicare Part A claims on Sept. 30 after 33 years, said a new processing company had not been named yet. The cuts come in the administration of Medicare Part A, which covers costs mainly associated with hospital expenses under the Federal health insurance program for the elderly. Trigon said benefits of members whose claims Trigon now processes would not change.

headline.main: TRIGON HEALTHCARE TO STOP PROCESSING SOME CLAIMS

docs.lead_paragraph: With Gov. George E. Pataki and lawmakers sniping their way to stalemates on even trivial matters, there haven't been a lot of laws made in Albany lately (not to mention a state budget now five weeks late). But it wouldn't be accurate to say that nothing is happening. More so than in recent years, the houses of the Legislature have gone their own ways, as if they had taken up residence in different states. The Republican majority in the State Senate has pushed through significant measures on school violence, school bus safety, stalking, abortion, tax cuts, sexual assault and state debt.

headline.main: Albany Notes; Houses Stay Busy, and Deadlocked

docs.abstract: There have not been lot of laws made in Albany lately, with Gov George E Pataki and lawmakers sniping their way to stalemates on even trivial matters; Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver has tried to turn Pataki's national aspirations against him, contending that he is neglecting his duties because he is parading before Republican groups across country (M)
